trans-unit.source: PolyBase in SQL Data Warehouse Tutorial | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: PolyBase in SQL Data Warehouse Tutorial | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn what PolyBase is and how to use it for data warehousing scenarios.
trans-unit.target: Learn what PolyBase is and how to use it for data warehousing scenarios.

trans-unit.source: Load data with PolyBase
trans-unit.target: Load data with PolyBase

trans-unit.source: PolyBase technology allows you to query and join data from multiple sources, all by using Transact-SQL commands.
trans-unit.target: PolyBase technology allows you to query and join data from multiple sources, all by using Transact-SQL commands.

trans-unit.source: Using PolyBase, you can query data stored in Azure blob storage and load it into SQL Data
trans-unit.target: Using PolyBase, you can query data stored in Azure blob storage and load it into SQL Data

trans-unit.source: Warehouse database with the following steps:
trans-unit.target: Warehouse database with the following steps:

trans-unit.source: Create database master key and credential.
trans-unit.target: Create database master key and credential.

trans-unit.source: Create PolyBase objects: external data source, external file format, and external table.
trans-unit.target: Create PolyBase objects: external data source, external file format, and external table.

trans-unit.source: Query data stored in Azure blob storage.
trans-unit.target: Query data stored in Azure blob storage.

trans-unit.source: Load data from Azure blob storage into SQL Data Warehouse.
trans-unit.target: Load data from Azure blob storage into SQL Data Warehouse.

trans-unit.source: Prerequisites
trans-unit.target: Prerequisites

trans-unit.source: To step through this tutorial, you need:
trans-unit.target: To step through this tutorial, you need:

trans-unit.source: Azure storage account
trans-unit.target: Azure storage account

trans-unit.source: Your data stored in Azure blob storage as delimited text files
trans-unit.target: Your data stored in Azure blob storage as delimited text files

trans-unit.source: First, you will create the objects that PolyBase requires for connecting to and querying data in Azure blob storage.
trans-unit.target: First, you will create the objects that PolyBase requires for connecting to and querying data in Azure blob storage.

trans-unit.source: Create database master key
trans-unit.target: Create database master key

trans-unit.source: Connect to user database on your server to create a database master key.
trans-unit.target: Connect to user database on your server to create a database master key.

trans-unit.source: This key is used to encrypt your credential secret in the next step.
trans-unit.target: This key is used to encrypt your credential secret in the next step.

trans-unit.source: Reference topic: <link><linkText>CREATE MASTER KEY (Transact-SQL)[]</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Reference topic: <link><linkText>CREATE MASTER KEY (Transact-SQL)[]</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Create a database scoped credential
trans-unit.target: Create a database scoped credential

trans-unit.source: To access Azure blob storage, you need to create a database scoped credential that stores authentication information for your Azure storage account.
trans-unit.target: To access Azure blob storage, you need to create a database scoped credential that stores authentication information for your Azure storage account.

trans-unit.source: Connect to your data warehouse database and create a database scoped credential for each Azure storage account you want to access.
trans-unit.target: Connect to your data warehouse database and create a database scoped credential for each Azure storage account you want to access.

trans-unit.source: Specify an identity name and your Azure storage account key as the Secret.
trans-unit.target: Specify an identity name and your Azure storage account key as the Secret.

trans-unit.source: The identity name does not affect authentication to Azure Storage.
trans-unit.target: The identity name does not affect authentication to Azure Storage.

trans-unit.source: To see if a database-scoped credential already exists, use sys.database_credentials, not sys.credentials which only shows the server credentials.
trans-unit.target: To see if a database-scoped credential already exists, use sys.database_credentials, not sys.credentials which only shows the server credentials.

trans-unit.source: Reference topic: <link><linkText>CREATE CREDENTIAL (Transact-SQL)[]</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Reference topic: <link><linkText>CREATE CREDENTIAL (Transact-SQL)[]</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: To drop a database scoped credential you simply use the following syntax:
trans-unit.target: To drop a database scoped credential you simply use the following syntax:

trans-unit.source: Reference topic: <link><linkText>DROP CREDENTIAL (Transact-SQL)[]</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Reference topic: <link><linkText>DROP CREDENTIAL (Transact-SQL)[]</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Create an external data source
trans-unit.target: Create an external data source

trans-unit.source: The external data source is a database object that stores the location of the Azure blob storage data and your access information.
trans-unit.target: The external data source is a database object that stores the location of the Azure blob storage data and your access information.

trans-unit.source: You need to define an external data source for each Azure Storage container you want to access.
trans-unit.target: You need to define an external data source for each Azure Storage container you want to access.

trans-unit.source: Reference topic: <link><linkText>CREATE EXTERNAL DATA SOURCE (Transact-SQL)[]</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Reference topic: <link><linkText>CREATE EXTERNAL DATA SOURCE (Transact-SQL)[]</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: To drop the external data source the syntax is as follows:
trans-unit.target: To drop the external data source the syntax is as follows:

trans-unit.source: Reference topic: <link><linkText>DROP EXTERNAL DATA SOURCE (Transact-SQL)[]</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Reference topic: <link><linkText>DROP EXTERNAL DATA SOURCE (Transact-SQL)[]</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Create an external file format
trans-unit.target: Create an external file format

trans-unit.source: The external file format is a database object that specifies the format of the external data.
trans-unit.target: The external file format is a database object that specifies the format of the external data.

trans-unit.source: In this example, we have uncompressed data in a text file and the fields are separated with the pipe character ('|').
trans-unit.target: In this example, we have uncompressed data in a text file and the fields are separated with the pipe character ('|').

trans-unit.source: PolyBase can work with compressed and uncompressed data in delimited text, Hive RCFILE and HIVE ORC formats.
trans-unit.target: PolyBase can work with compressed and uncompressed data in delimited text, Hive RCFILE and HIVE ORC formats.

trans-unit.source: Reference topic: <link><linkText>CREATE EXTERNAL FILE FORMAT (Transact-SQL)[]</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Reference topic: <link><linkText>CREATE EXTERNAL FILE FORMAT (Transact-SQL)[]</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: To drop an external file format the syntax is as follows:
trans-unit.target: To drop an external file format the syntax is as follows:

trans-unit.source: Reference topic: <link><linkText>DROP EXTERNAL FILE FORMAT (Transact-SQL)[]</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Reference topic: <link><linkText>DROP EXTERNAL FILE FORMAT (Transact-SQL)[]</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Create an external table
trans-unit.target: Create an external table

trans-unit.source: The external table definition is similar to a relational table definition.
trans-unit.target: The external table definition is similar to a relational table definition.

trans-unit.source: The key difference is the location and the format of the data.
trans-unit.target: The key difference is the location and the format of the data.

trans-unit.source: The external table definition is stored in the SQL Data Warehouse database.
trans-unit.target: The external table definition is stored in the SQL Data Warehouse database.

trans-unit.source: The data is stored in the location specified by the data source.
trans-unit.target: The data is stored in the location specified by the data source.

trans-unit.source: The LOCATION option specifies the path to the data from the root of the data source.
trans-unit.target: The LOCATION option specifies the path to the data from the root of the data source.

trans-unit.source: In this example, the data is located at 'wasbs://mycontainer@ test.blob.core.windows.net/path/Demo/'.
trans-unit.target: In this example, the data is located at 'wasbs://mycontainer@ test.blob.core.windows.net/path/Demo/'.

trans-unit.source: All the files for the same table need to be under the same logical folder in Azure BLOB.
trans-unit.target: All the files for the same table need to be under the same logical folder in Azure BLOB.

trans-unit.source: Please note that you cannot create statistics on an external table at this time.
trans-unit.target: Please note that you cannot create statistics on an external table at this time.

trans-unit.source: Reference topic: <link><linkText>CREATE EXTERNAL TABLE (Transact-SQL)[]</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Reference topic: <link><linkText>CREATE EXTERNAL TABLE (Transact-SQL)[]</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: The objects you just created are stored in SQL Data Warehouse database.
trans-unit.target: The objects you just created are stored in SQL Data Warehouse database.

trans-unit.source: You can view them in the SQL Server Data Tools (SSDT) Object Explorer.
trans-unit.target: You can view them in the SQL Server Data Tools (SSDT) Object Explorer.

trans-unit.source: To drop an external table you need to use the following syntax:
trans-unit.target: To drop an external table you need to use the following syntax:

trans-unit.source: When dropping an external table you must use DROP EXTERNAL TABLE you cannot use DROP TABLE.
trans-unit.target: When dropping an external table you must use DROP EXTERNAL TABLE you cannot use DROP TABLE.

trans-unit.source: Reference topic: <link><linkText>DROP EXTERNAL TABLE (Transact-SQL)[]</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Reference topic: <link><linkText>DROP EXTERNAL TABLE (Transact-SQL)[]</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: It is also worth noting that external tables are visible in both sys.tables and more specifically in sys.external_tables catalog views.
trans-unit.target: It is also worth noting that external tables are visible in both sys.tables and more specifically in sys.external_tables catalog views.

trans-unit.source: Rotating storage keys
trans-unit.target: Rotating storage keys

trans-unit.source: From time to time you will want to change the access key to your blob storage for security reasons.
trans-unit.target: From time to time you will want to change the access key to your blob storage for security reasons.

trans-unit.source: The most elegant way to perform this task is to follow a process known as "rotating the keys".
trans-unit.target: The most elegant way to perform this task is to follow a process known as "rotating the keys".

trans-unit.source: You may have noticed that you have two storage keys for your blob storage account.
trans-unit.target: You may have noticed that you have two storage keys for your blob storage account.

trans-unit.source: This is so that you can transition
trans-unit.target: This is so that you can transition

trans-unit.source: Rotating your Azure storage account keys is a simple three step process
trans-unit.target: Rotating your Azure storage account keys is a simple three step process

trans-unit.source: Create second database scoped credential based on the secondary storage access key
trans-unit.target: Create second database scoped credential based on the secondary storage access key

trans-unit.source: Create second external data source based off this new credential
trans-unit.target: Create second external data source based off this new credential

trans-unit.source: Drop and create the external table(s) pointing to the new external data source
trans-unit.target: Drop and create the external table(s) pointing to the new external data source

trans-unit.source: When you have migrated all your external tables to the new external data source then you can perform the clean up tasks:
trans-unit.target: When you have migrated all your external tables to the new external data source then you can perform the clean up tasks:

trans-unit.source: Drop first external data source
trans-unit.target: Drop first external data source

trans-unit.source: Drop first database scoped credential based on the primary storage access key
trans-unit.target: Drop first database scoped credential based on the primary storage access key

trans-unit.source: Log into Azure and regenerate the primary access key ready for the next time
trans-unit.target: Log into Azure and regenerate the primary access key ready for the next time

trans-unit.source: Query Azure blob storage data
trans-unit.target: Query Azure blob storage data

trans-unit.source: Queries against external tables simply use the table name as though it was a relational table.
trans-unit.target: Queries against external tables simply use the table name as though it was a relational table.

trans-unit.source: This is an ad-hoc query that joins insurance customer data stored in SQL Data Warehouse, with automobile sensor data stored in Azure storage blob.
trans-unit.target: This is an ad-hoc query that joins insurance customer data stored in SQL Data Warehouse, with automobile sensor data stored in Azure storage blob.

trans-unit.source: The result shows the drivers that drive faster than others.
trans-unit.target: The result shows the drivers that drive faster than others.

trans-unit.source: Load data from Azure blob storage
trans-unit.target: Load data from Azure blob storage

trans-unit.source: This example loads data from Azure blob storage to SQL Data Warehouse database.
trans-unit.target: This example loads data from Azure blob storage to SQL Data Warehouse database.

trans-unit.source: Storing data directly removes the data transfer time for queries.
trans-unit.target: Storing data directly removes the data transfer time for queries.

trans-unit.source: Storing data with a columnstore index improves query performance for analysis queries by up to 10x.
trans-unit.target: Storing data with a columnstore index improves query performance for analysis queries by up to 10x.

trans-unit.source: This example uses the CREATE TABLE AS SELECT statement to load data.
trans-unit.target: This example uses the CREATE TABLE AS SELECT statement to load data.

trans-unit.source: The new table inherits the columns named in the query.
trans-unit.target: The new table inherits the columns named in the query.

trans-unit.source: It inherits the data types of those columns from the external table definition.
trans-unit.target: It inherits the data types of those columns from the external table definition.

trans-unit.source: CREATE TABLE AS SELECT is a highly performant Transact-SQL statement that replaces INSERT...SELECT.
trans-unit.target: CREATE TABLE AS SELECT is a highly performant Transact-SQL statement that replaces INSERT...SELECT.

trans-unit.source: It was originally developed for the massively parallel processing (MPP) engine in Analytics Platform System and is now in SQL Data Warehouse.
trans-unit.target: It was originally developed for the massively parallel processing (MPP) engine in Analytics Platform System and is now in SQL Data Warehouse.

trans-unit.source: See <link><linkText>CREATE TABLE AS SELECT (Transact-SQL)[]</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: See <link><linkText>CREATE TABLE AS SELECT (Transact-SQL)[]</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Working around the PolyBase UTF-8 requirement
trans-unit.target: Working around the PolyBase UTF-8 requirement

trans-unit.source: At present PolyBase supports loading data files that have been UTF-8 encoded.
trans-unit.target: At present PolyBase supports loading data files that have been UTF-8 encoded.

trans-unit.source: As UTF-8 uses the same character encoding as ASCII PolyBase will also support loading data that is ASCII encoded.
trans-unit.target: As UTF-8 uses the same character encoding as ASCII PolyBase will also support loading data that is ASCII encoded.

trans-unit.source: However, PolyBase does not support other character encoding such as UTF-16 / Unicode or extended ASCII characters.
trans-unit.target: However, PolyBase does not support other character encoding such as UTF-16 / Unicode or extended ASCII characters.

trans-unit.source: Extended ASCII includes characters with accents such as the umlaut which is common in German.
trans-unit.target: Extended ASCII includes characters with accents such as the umlaut which is common in German.

trans-unit.source: To work around this requirement the best answer is to re-write to UTF-8 encoding.
trans-unit.target: To work around this requirement the best answer is to re-write to UTF-8 encoding.

trans-unit.source: There are several ways to do this.
trans-unit.target: There are several ways to do this.

trans-unit.source: Below are two approaches using Powershell:
trans-unit.target: Below are two approaches using Powershell:

trans-unit.source: Simple example for small files
trans-unit.target: Simple example for small files

trans-unit.source: Below is a simple one line Powershell script that creates the file.
trans-unit.target: Below is a simple one line Powershell script that creates the file.

trans-unit.source: However, whilst this is a simple way to re-encode the data it is by no means the most efficient.
trans-unit.target: However, whilst this is a simple way to re-encode the data it is by no means the most efficient.

trans-unit.source: The io streaming example below is much, much faster and achieves the same result.
trans-unit.target: The io streaming example below is much, much faster and achieves the same result.

trans-unit.source: IO Streaming example for larger files
trans-unit.target: IO Streaming example for larger files

trans-unit.source: The code sample below is more complex but as it streams the rows of data from source to target it is much more efficient.
trans-unit.target: The code sample below is more complex but as it streams the rows of data from source to target it is much more efficient.

trans-unit.source: Use this approach for larger files.
trans-unit.target: Use this approach for larger files.
